iv  A. BACKGROUND AND STRATEGY
1. ProjectRationale
Late 2005 saw the culmination o f the political transformation established for Afghanistan by the Bonnagreement in2001,forming the basis for the state-building and development ina country emerging fromnearlythree decadesofconflict andpolitical turmoil.
Despite unmet expectations for some o f the population, Afghanistan's progress in some sectors has been impressive - development o f road networks had reduced travel times and improved rural access; school enrolments have reached historic highs; health facilities are gaining outreach; thousands o f rural communities have been mobilized for development; commercial banks have opened up for business andmicrofinance programs have extended services to thousands, predominantly women. Real GDP, excluding opium production, i s projectedto grow by 14 percent in2005/06 (SY 1384), following increases o f 29 percent in 2002/03, 16 percent in 2003/04 and 8 percent in 2004/05. However, the situation i s far from normalized and the country has not fully emerged from its state o f conflict. For every success, there remain formidable, numerous challenges.
These challenges are particularly demanding in rural Afghanistan, which i s home to nearly 80 percent o f the population, and where incidence o f rural poverty is high, penetration o f insurgency growing, and opium production booming as the country recovers from the long-term effects o f the recently ended six-year drought.
To address state building, local governance, warlordism, and to urgently provide basic rural infrastructure for irrigation, drinking water, electrification, rural roads and school the government has promoted since 2003 a massive effort to outreach rural communities through the National Solidarity Program (NSP). The NSP, supported by the International Development Association (IDA) and several donors, has been progressing successfully in the last three years quickly positioning itself as the government's most tangible intervention in rural areas, significantly contributing to the process o f pacification, democratization andreconstruction.
Executedby the Ministry o f Rural Rehabilitation andDevelopment (MRRD)on behalf o f the Government o f Afghanistan, the NSP first commenced as a component o f the Emergency Community Empowerment & Public Works Project inJune 2002 (HOO9-AF, closed in Dec 31, 2004). It became a full fledged National Priority Program in 2003 under Afghanistan's National Development Framework and over the last three years has grown to become the government's flagship rural development program, with its outreach extending to more than half the rural population across all 34 provinces o f the country (Map 1).
Known inDari as Hambastagi Milli and inPashtu as Milli Paiwastoon, the NSP targets the needs o frural communities through a community-driven approach and a collaborative partnership encompassing central andprovincial government, local and international non- governmental organizations (NGOs), andthe communities themselves.
1  Implemented by the MRRD through an extensive network o f contracted Facilitating Partners (FPs), the NSP: (i) Facilitates a process o f establishing inclusive, voluntary community institutions (Community Development Councils, CDCs) through democratic elections, reaching consensus on development priorities, developing eligible investment proposals, and implementing community projects; (ii)Provides direct Block Grant transfers to a bank account established inthe name o f the CDCs to support rehabilitation and development activities planned and implemented by the elected CDCs; (iii) Builds capacity to enhance the competence of members o f CDCs (men and women) interms o f financial management, procurement, technical skills, and transparency; and (iv) Links local institutions to government administration and aid agencies with available services andresources.
The NSP is very popular in Afghanistan. The program i s widely recognized as the main instrument for strengthening local governance and supporting the planning and implementation o f community-based subprojects that invariably generate labor for the poor, stimulate local economies, andprovide basic rural infrastructure.
2. Government Strategy
The NSP i s the main instrument o f the Government for restoring and reconstructing the village social and economic infrastructure. It will be a key vehicle in the delivery o f the benchmarks for the L A N D S Agriculture andRural Development pillar, particularly inthe areas o f rural infrastructure and community development. NSP community projects cover nearly all the areas o f priority investments for rural infrastructure: drinking water, sanitation, small-scale irrigation, roads and structures, schools andvillage electrification.
Article 140 o f the Constitution o f Afghanistan stipulates that `In order to organize activities involving people and provide them with the opportunity to actively participate inthe local administration, councils are setup indistricts andvillages inaccordance with the provisions o f the law. Members o f these councils are elected by the local people through, free, general, secret anddirect elections for a period of three years.'
Along with the impelling need to rebuild and rehabilitate basic rural infrastructure, the government strategy i s therefore to establish the CDC as the democratically recognized, development body at the community level inthe whole of Afghanistan. Toward this end, the MRRD is committed to creating a CDC constitution to provide legal status to the CDCs inthe future. As a first step toward this goal, MRRDhas made substantial progress in drafting a CDC by-law. The draft CDC by-law recognizes the CDCs as the lowest form o f local governance, institutionalized at the village level, in line with the Constitution. It also recognizes the CDC as the interface between the government and the communities for the decision making, planning and implementation o f all rural development inventions o f the other government ministries and agencies. The CDC by- law i s expected to be submitted to the President for approval after review by the National Steering Committee in the forthcoming months. This will take the country one step further to realizing their Constitution and to consolidate the democratization process which began in2002.
2  Official recognition and future CDC legislation would enable CDCs to have a legal footing to harness resources from other relevant government ministries, development actors, and aid agencies. Additionally, the MRRD recognizes that the role o f the CDC must be strengthened through coordination with different line ministries as the entry- point for development interventions targeting communities (health, infrastructure, education, natural resource management) and through linkages with the existing sub- national administrations.
For the purpose o f the proposed IDA Grant, the government has developed a seven year vision which includes the initial phase o f three years to reach out to all rural communities, so that every rural village is represented by a CDC, and the final phase o f four years to consolidate assistance to the communities within an exit strategy that sees the termination o f the NSP as a program, andthe empowerment o f the CDCs as officially recognized, local development entities.
B. BANKRESPONSEAND STRATEGY
1. TheNSPandthe I-ANDs
NSP is making a significant contribution towards achieving the vision and goals o f the Government o f Afghanistan set out in the interim-Afghanistan National Development Strategy (I-ANDs) which will lay out the basis for an Afghanistan Poverty Reduction Strategy. The NSP is directly in line with the overall vision for the Islamic Republic o f Afghanistan, `to consolidate peace and stability through just, democratic processes and institutions, and to reduce poverty and achieve prosperity through broad based and equitable economic growth'. The NSP objectives and achievements to date are in line with overall poverty reduction objective o fthe Bank.
Since its inception, the NSP has covered 274 districts in all 34 provinces o f Afghanistan. As o f September 2006, 17,278 communities have been contracted to Facilitating Partners (FPs) with 14,820 communities mobilized and 14,120 Community Development Councils elected representing an estimated thirteen million people. About 9,3 15 CDCs had received block grants to fund 17,026 subprojects. A total o f 7,455 priority subprojects had been completed with 10,113 subproject proposals approved and currently being implemented by the communities themselves. A further 2,741 subprojects have been approved and are waiting for their first block grant disbursement to begin implementation. A total o f US$246.1 million has been committed to fimd approved subprojects o f which US$ 200.9 million has been disbursed directly to communities. IDAhas financed $138 millionto NSP to date.
Returns on NSP outputs are immediate, and the evidence suggests that their benefits to villagers are high. A sample o f subprojects selected for economic analysis showed economic rates o f return (ERR) averaging 26.3 to 60.8 percent, with an overall ERR weighted average o f 38.2 percent.
3  Communities have consistently prioritized infrastructure projects for their block grants and on average implement two subprojects with their allocations. More than halfo f the community projects involve productive infrastructure such as irrigation, roads and village electrification thereby promoting productivity and stimulating local economies. A further 26 percent involves safe water and sanitation which assures better health for the communities. More than 80 percent o f all labor generated by the subprojects is absorbed within the communities, with 16.6 million labor days already created, giving the poor income generating opportunities. Community implemented subprojects have also proven to be the most cost-effective delivery mechanism for rural infrastructure, often costing 50 percent or less thanthe alternative options on the market.
3. Rationale for Bank Involvement
InMay 2006, the World Bank Board of Executive Directors discussed a new Interim Strategy Note (ISN) for Afghanistan, which guides the Bank`s engagement for the next two years, and is aligned with the government's InterimNational Development Strategy (I-ANDs). The ISNenvisages a grant program o f up to US$540 million over those two years, which i s inline with the World Bank's five-year pledge o f US$1.2 billion made at the January 2006 London Conference. Under the ISN, the World Bank priorities are: (i) buildingthe capacity and accountability of the state, (ii) improving rural livelihoods and promoting rural economy, and (iii)supporting the growth o f a formal, modern, and competitive private sector. Because o f its design and outreach, the NSP i s considered one o fthe key instrumentsto achieve these objectives.

1. ProjectObjective
Buildingon the current NSP, the proposed IDA Grant will scale up the program to "lay the foundations for strengthening o f community level governance, and to support community-managed subprojects comprising reconstruction and development that improve access o f rural communities to social and productive infrastructure and services".
Reaching out to an estimated additional 4,318 new villages, the NSP will (i) establish a framework for village level consultative decision making and representative local leadership as a basis for interaction within and between communities on the one hand, and with the administration and aid agencies on the other, (ii) implement social and economic productive activities addressing the basic village needs, and (iii)develop humancapitalandlivelihoodwhich will improve householdwelfare.
The government o f Afghanistan envisions the roll-out the program across the entire country inthe next three years or phase I1o f the NSP for a total cost o f US$525 million which includes a back-log o f US$ 90 million from the current phase. This amount i s expected to be financed through IDA, ARTF, JSDF andbilateral resources.
2. ProjectComponents
The Grant will finance about 23 percent o f the total projected cost o fthe National Solidarity Program inthe next three years and for the following components:
(i)Block Grants for communities (US$94.3 million) to carry out subprojects involving reconstruction and development activities through a facilitated participatory planning process. This will cover about a third o f the amount estimated to complete block grant disbursement to existing and new communities (US$288 million) for the whole program. While the use o f block grants i s demand- driven following each Community Development Plan priorities, based on the experience gained in the program to date it i s expected that block grants will be invested mainly on community-based productive and social infrastructure such as irrigation works, roads including culverts and small bridges, erosion protection, structures promoting watershed management, water supply facilities, micro- hydropower, school buildings etc.
(ii)Community Facilitation and Subproject Preparation (US$9.7 million) to support local communities through: (i) facilitation exercises to establish inclusive community institutions (CDCs), and identify local development needs and priorities; and (ii) assistance for preparing subproject proposals. 3. ProjectDescription
The project description reflects the operational policies described in detail in the NSP OperationalManual (OM), which are summarized below.
Approach: The NSP provides a single-window framework for village level reconstruction and development activities. It consists o f four core elements: (i) Facilitation at the community level to assist communities establish inclusive community institutions through secret ballot and democratic elections; reach consensus on priorities and corresponding subproject activities; develop eligible sub-proposals that comply with NSP appraisal criteria; and implement approved project sub-proposals; (ii) A system o f direct block grant transfers to support rehabilitation or development activities (subprojects) planned and implementedbythe elected CDCs; (iii) Capacitybuildingthe capacities of CDC and community members (men andwomen) inparticipation, consensus building, financial management and accounting, procurement and contract management, operations and maintenance, and monitoring; and (iv) Activities linking CDCs to government agencies,NGOsand donorsto improve accessto services andresources.
Coverage: Each year MRRD develops a NSP roll-out plan that identifies target districts and establishes the total number o f communities within each district to be mobilized. Districts are selected based on vulnerability factors (level o f poverty and risk o f drought or food insecurity), the number o f returnees or internally displaced persons, and security conditions.
Community Development Councils: Communities are identified on the basis o f existing local settlement and social patterns. However, this will not prevent different distinct villages, whether small or large, from joining together to develop assets (e.g. a school, a
6  pipe water system, or a road) that serve more than one village. The CDC is responsible for: (i)Overseeing preparation o f the Community Development Plan (CDP) with prioritized needs and subproject activities that address these needs; (ii)Convening community wide meetings to ensure community participation during all phases; (iii) Overseeing planning and preparation o f specific subprojects either directly or through community project management committees; (iv) Mobilizing community contributions; (v) Presenting subproject plans for appraisal; (vi) Managing and supervising subproject implementation with assistance from the Facilitating Partner agency; (vii) Overseeing (or directly handling) procurement and financial management at the community level; and (viii) Reporting to the community andto MFNDonproject progress anduse o f funds.
Elections: The CDC is established through an election conducted according to the following rules: (i) Everybody inthe community (both men and women) who i s entitled to vote ingovernment elections is eligible to be registeredas a voter; (ii) Eachpersonhas one vote; (iii)The voting will be conducted through a secret ballot; (iv) Candidates and electioneering is prohibited; (v) At least 60 percent o f eligible voters have to vote for an election to be valid; (vi) The FP must verify the accuracy o f the cast ballots on a sample basis; and (vii) Only one CDC is elected per community. After the election, the CDCs are registeredwith MRRD.
To ensure inclusiveness interms o f different socio-economic, factional, and ethndtribal (qaum) sub-divisions within the community, the electionprocess i s based on a division o f the community into groups o f families (clusters). Each cluster elects two representatives for the CDC: one male and one female. Since neighbors are usually also relatives, this approach will reduce purdah restrictions on women and thereby facilitate their active involvement in discussions and the election. Cluster sizes will vary depending on the size o f the community, but should not exceed about 20 families. The clusters will also serve as the framework for community-wide consultations, whereby elected members meet with and seek feedback from their electorate before making decisions on priorities, subprojects, and community contributions.
Experience from NSP Iindicates that equity can be achieved even in extremely conservative communities if the basic equity principles are presented early in the mobilization process and time is taken to work with community leaders to identify ways in which the principles can be honored without compromising cultural and religious norms.
InNSP I1there are no longer separatemale or female CDCs. Communities may choose to establish Men's and Women's Sub-Committees where it is not possible for men and women to meet together for cultural and/or religious reasons. Insuch cases, four officers for each sub-committee are elected and an Executive Coordination Committee is established, comprising two officers from each Sub-committee.
Block grant allocations to villages are based on the following three principles: (i) One block grant (budget) will be allocated to each CDC at a rate o f US$200 per family with an upper limit o f US$60,000 per community. This allocation requires that the
7  community develops one or more eligible subproject proposals within the framework o f the block grant allocation and its own contributions; (ii) One CDC will be established for each community. CDCs cannot be established for sub-sets o f an existing village (e.g., a village can not be split into its constituent political or ethnickinship (qaum) sub- divisions); and (iii) community is a village o f more than 25 families. A However, clusters o f adjoining communities may opt and are encouraged to pool up their block grant entitlements and allocations to plan and implement subprojects o f common interest andbenefit to them.
Eligibility: Inorder to be eligible for ablock grant allocation, a community must develop one or more subproject proposals that fulfill the following criteria: (i) Subproject is proposed by a CDC that has been elected in accordance with the NSP guidelines; (ii) Subproject is endorsed by the community through a community-wide consultative process; (iii) Subproject provides equitable access to benefits; (iv) At least one subproject identified by women as a priority must be targeted for NSP funding; (v) Subproject is technically and financially sound (uses the engineering specifications in the Technical Manual, where appropriate); (vi) Subproject is compatible with social, environmental, andmine risk safeguards; (vii) The community has committed to contributing an amount equal to at least 10 percent o f the Block Grant towards costs o f proposed subproject(s); (viii) Subproject has an Operations andMaintenance Plan; and (ix) The CDC commits to ensuring transparency inthe use o f Block Grant funds.
Subproiects: Two types o f subprojects are financed under NSP: (i)Community infrastructure (the investments will comply with defined technical standards described in the NSP Technical Manual, and only comprise public goods);' and (ii) Humancapital development activities (e.g., time-bound literacy classes, hygiene education etc, that will not incur recurrent costs from the state).
In the case of subproject proposals involving rehabilitation or new construction of schools, a condition for approval is the endorsement by the Ministryo f Education that the proposed school fits within the overall planning o f the ministry, and that the ministry will cover the operating costs o f the school (fully or with committed contributions from other agencies). If undertaken, rehabilitation and new construction of clinics will require careful planningand coordination.
Inclusion o f new returnees (refugees and Internally Displaced Persons who return to the community after the initial CDC election i s held): Ifmore than 20 families return, the FP facilitates a sub-election for each returnee cluster (comprised o f 20 families each) within one month o f their return andthe community incorporates the new cluster representatives into the CDC. The CDC revises the CDC Registration Application accordingly and submits to the OC. If less than 20 families return, no elections are held but the CDC is responsible for ensuring that returnees are encouraged to participate fully in subproject committees and all program activities.
Such infrastructure projects would include, but not necessarily be restrictedto irrigationworks, roads including culverts and small bridges, erosion protection, structures promoting watershed management, water supply facilities, village electrification projects (ex. micro-hydropower), and school buildings.
8  Community Development Plan and Subproiect Proposals: In consultation with the community at large, the CDC develops a Community Development Plan (CDP) that prioritizes the specific needs o f the community, and proposes subprojects that address these needs. The facilitation o f an inclusive planning process in which various stakeholders and interest groups have an opportunity to discuss their priorities is a key step in the NSP methodology. The process promotes dialogue on community potentials, opportunities and needs to produce a planthat i s holistic and strategic. It provides a basis for coordinated government interventions at the community level, as well as sectoral planningat the district, provincial andnational levels.

D. INSTITUTIONALARRANGEMENTSAND PROJECTIMPLEMENTATION
1. Introduction
Duringthe first three years o f implementation o f the NSP the MRRD has been assisted by an internationally recruited Oversight Consultant (OC) to carry out the overall management o f the program. Facilitation o f and technical guidance for the village level project planning and implementation was outsourced to 24 international and national NGOs (facilitating partners, FPs) and a UNagency. The FPs facilitated the mobilization o f the target communities to form the CDCs and to provide them with technical guidance for the management o f block grants and planning and implementation o f the subprojects at village level using the block grants.
The program was initially centralized. However, during the course o f the last two years five regional offices have been established, and regional and provincial management capacity has been slowly but consistently developed and strengthened, and project oversight has been gradually decentralized to regional andprovincial offices.
Most of MRRD civil servants at the central and provincial levels have been integrated into the NSP management structure over the past two years. Two MRRD staff from every province has been seconded to the provincial NSP OC offices to provide additional engineering andmonitoring support.
Taking into account the challenges and constraints that continue to be posed by the operating environment, the NSP I1 institutional arrangements build on successful elements o f the existing structure, but significant adjustments have also been introduced, with a special attention to the institutional strengthening of the MRRD, reduction of delivery costs, security riskmitigation, and decentralizationo f the program management.

ManaPement Support Consultant (MSC)
MRRD would hire a Management Support Consultant through international competition to take responsibility for financial management, block grant management and MIS. Outsourcing these functions aims to ensure accountability and transparency to donors and stakeholders, and compliance with World Bank fiduciary rules andregulations. The main management support responsibilities o f the MSC will include budget and financial management, financial procedures & controls, personnel administration, MIS, IT and database and other management related information provision.
At the field level, seven Regional Offices (ROs) will support the provincial RRD offices inapprovingblock grants, liaisonwithFPs, overseeingthe procurement administrationof subprojects andbuildlocal management capacities o f the provincial staff through on-the- job training. The Provincial RRD offices will be responsible for overseeing the work o f the FPs and for managing the outcome o f the NSP: the mobilization o f the communities, formation o f the CDCs and planningand implementation o f the subprojects.

Implementation inHighRisk Areas
The security environment inwhich the NSP operates has significantly deteriorated over the course o f the program and is currently at its worst level. The number o f communities and districts where NSP activities are suspended has steadily increased. The security situation remains highly volatile and i s the single most important risk the NSP I1faces to achieve its stated goals.
The deterioration insecurity presents a number o f dilemmas. The government has made a commitment to bringthe NSP to all rural communities, and communities yet to start with the NSP are impatient. As part o f the national government, MRRD has the political mandate and commitment to roll out to all areas o f the country. The NSP to date has been considered by the communities as an effective rural development and village governance/state building program. Its presence has ensured government visibility and the perception that the government is taking responsibility for its citizens, even in the most remote rural areas. It is also the Government's main vehicle to achieve rural development benchmarks o f the I-ANDs. Precisely because NSP promotes the existing government's interests, however, it has been targeted by anti-government elements linked to drug trafficking, terrorist groups, and insurgency. If the NSP suspends its activities, there i s a political risk that the absence o f government and support in those areas would provide an advantage to anti-government elements to win sympathy and support from the people inthose areas. On the other hand, to continue the NSP activities poses enormous challenges o f physical insecurity (in the last year the number and casualties doubled), higher delivery costs, and limited supervision (and therefore technical, fiduciary and safeguard risks).
The planning o f the implementation o f NSP I1in high risk areas therefore requires to strike a pragmatic balance between the state building objectives o f the Government and need to comply with the development effectiveness and outcomes as well as the diligent fiduciary management o f the project.
Extensive discussions have taken place with the FPs operating in insecure areas and between the government and the OC to identify various options for planning and implementing the NSP I1in high risk areas. Map 1 shows the districts where FPs are

Districts rated at low risk at present may become highrisk area and vice versa during the course o f the implementation, andplanning o f the roll out will needto be adjusted accordingly.
Based on the current estimate, the NSP I1 is expected to cover an additional 4,318 villages in the next three years. This number is subject to change, however, due to the dynamic and unpredictable nature o f the security situation. Sufficient flexibility has therefore been incorporated in the cost tables and procurement planning. Actual rolling out to new communities and districts will be adjusted during the implementation with guidance from the National Steering Committee after proper assessment o f the security conditions.
Unwillingness o f the FP andprovincial/district staff to travel to risk prone villages could undermine the achievement o f the development objectives o f the NSP 11. The restricted accessibility would pose many other potential programmatic, fiduciary, and reputational risks. These include: (i) inability to mobilize and train CDCs to ensure transparency and equity in carrying out a democratic election leading to potential risk o f capturing the decisionmakingpower o f CDCs and misappropriation o f fundingby elites, warlords, and anti-government elements; (ii) inability to supervise diligently, the financial management and procurement administration o f the subprojects and block grant disbursements and accounting; (iii)reduced quality of the design, billing and construction of the subprojects leading to potential avenues o f corruption, potential risk o f block grants ending up partially in the hands o f anti-government elements, and questionable usefulness and sustainability o f the subprojects; and (iv) risk to life o f the operating staff.
Under these circumstances, it is very difficult to filly respect the NSP guiding principles inpursuit of the NSP objectives ininsecure areas. Inhighrisk areas the main threat to the NSP objectives is the inability to establish the foundation for local governance, as FPs have restricted access to the communities and therefore cannot offer the full facilitation support to develop the capacity o f the CDCs and to ensure the CDCs are representative and consultative in their formulation o f the community development plan. As a result, the focus is more on the delivery o f state building services, rather than inclusive local governance. This means that any alternative approach is only realistic in communities that have already been mobilized, elected their CDCs, formulated their development plans, andwhere subprojects have already been reviewed and approved by the OC. It is not possible to facilitate the governance component o f the program by remote control, when FPs cannot access the communities.
Therefore, it has been agreed that the project, through the National Steering Committee, will obtain guidance for program planning and implementation in the high risk areas, particularly for the roll out to new communities and new districts. If the accessibility o f these villages and districts is restricted, the program roll out to new communities andnew districts will not take place until the Steering Committee recommends that the security situation has eased off, the concerned Communities are willing to receive the services o f
14  FPs, the concerned FP and the staff o f the Regional staff are willing to travel to those areas, and the Bank task team i s confident that satisfactory arrangements for implementation supervision, monitoring and fiduciary compliance are inplace.
Inthe case of communities inhighrisk areas who have been partially mobilized and already included inthe ongoing FP contracts, a different distance based approach will be utilized. If in any village the CDC is already in place, CDP has been developed, and subprojects have been approved by the OC, then the CDC will allow to proceed with the implementation. Inthose instances, the subproject implementation would rely on trusted and respected independent community members, who could verify the use o f block grant funds andthe status of implementation. Inaddition, the project implementation will rely upon the monitoring by community level procurement and financial management sub- committees. However, technically complex subprojects, such as micro-hydro power, would not be implementedinthe absence o fproper technical support.
Based on the initial implementation experience with the above proxy oversight and monitoring arrangements, other possible alternative implementation approaches for the project implementation in risk areas would be explored later during the implementation phase.

1. Project Benefits
The NSP block grants are used to build economically productive infrastructure. Returns on NSP outputs are immediate and the evidence suggests that their benefits to villagers are high. A sample o f 22 NSP subprojects selected for economic analysis showed economic rates o f return (ERR) averaging 26.3 to 60.8 percent, with an overall ERR weighted average o f 38.2 percent, and a net present value (NPV) at US$1.186 million. These results were obtained assuming that 30 percent o f the NSP I1subprojects could fail because o f poor design and/or the growing conflicting situations inhighrisk areas. Water supply projects show the highest ERR at an average o f 60.8 percent due to their large benefits stemming from time and costs saved by family members for collecting and/or obtaining water. These figures do not yet include the benefits from improved health conditions due to the supply o f safe water. Road and bridge projects show an average ERR o f 26.6 percent, resulting from time savings and from significant increases in agricultural product sales, decrease in transport costs to bring products to market, and opening o f market opportunities. The irrigation projects show an ERR averaging 38.5 percent and the energy subprojects average an ERR at 26.3 percent. N o value was assigned to the improvement o f governance, nor to the benefits expected to be generated bythe follow-up projects that the CDCs are already implementing.
The economic sensitivity o f the program to the major risk facing the country was also tested. The on-going armed conflict could result in further aggravation o f the security situation in rural villages increasing the risk o f subproject sustainability. In the case subprojects failure would reach 50 percent instead o f the assumed 30 percent, the ERR could fall from 38.2 percent to 27 percent. On the contrary, ifthe situation improves and scheme failures drop to only 15 percent, the ERR could be increased to 46.4 percent. These results allow concluding that the NSP has a very low probability o f failure. It could be safely concluded that it is a very strong probability that the NSP will continue to be the strongest vehicle for the country's post-war reconstruction inrural areas.
A cost efficiency analysis was also conducted at two levels: (i) block grant delivery the costs (including MRRD, Oversight Consultants and FPs) as compared with international experience; and (ii)the cost comparison o f typical block grant investments at the community level, with other modalities o f investments for delivering the same services in Afghanistan. 2. Sustainability
Sustainability o fthe NSP
The project will cover the first three years o f a seven-year government proposal for the expansion and consolidation o f the program. There is no plan to extend NSP beyond the proposed seven years. Any further activity beyond that period applies to the community councils established through NSP, not to NSP itself. CDC's can play three important roles in the bigger picture o f Afghanistan's longer-term development. First, CDC's for the first time provide the central government with an effective means to deliver basic services across the entire country. Second, CDC's could carry out certain basic administrative functions provided that they received a core block grant through the budget. Third, CDC's could be grouped to provide representative planningbodies at the district level that would advise local government. These three options to a large extent hinge on the central government's vision for subnational government and administration. A more sustained role for CDC's would be equally compatible with continued centralization or ina more deconcentrated system.
27  Sustainabilitv o fthe CDCs
The central sustainability goal o f the government i s therefore to ensure the continuity o f the CDCs as a permanent part o f the governance system and for them to evolve to become the primary service delivery instrument for rural development. However, funds alone will not guarantee the long-term sustainability o f CDCs. A national public consultation o f elected CDCs found that their position as a representative institution in the villages will only be achieved if they secure legitimacy through legal recognition o f and status for the CDC as an institution. Without this, the CDC members rightlybelieve that they have no legitimacy in any political or developmental context outside o f the NSP. The CDCs must be recognized by all the government ministries and enshrined in the law of Afghanistan. Ifthe CDCs are legally constituted then they are far more likely to remain as an active institution far into the future, beyond the perceived timeframe o f the NSP itself. This legal status and recognition as an institution of local governance would enable the CDCs to seek funding external to the NSP.
The CDCs are intended to be the engines o f development at the village level and the CDPs include many activities that fall beyond the mandate o f MRRD. Ifthe CDCs are to have an ongoing role, it i s essential that they are properly utilized by other ministries and service providers in their activities aimed at the rural population. For the role o f the CDCs to be expanded to other ministries, it i s necessary to actively promote the potential offered by the CDCs as planning, decision making and service delivery instruments across the board.
Currently a draft by-law has been completed incoordinationwith the MRRD,Ministryo f Justice and Ministry o f Interior. The by-law has been endorsed by the Inter-Ministerial Steering Committee in October, 2006 and is expected to be approved by the President. On recommendation o f the Steering Committee, it i s expected that a Presidential Decree would be issued to all Government Ministries and agencies clarifying the nature, roles and responsibilities o f CDCs and Government's vision towards CDCs. One o f the important expected outcomes o f the decree would be the recognition o f CDCs as formal village level bodies that should be considered as the village level interface between the Government andcommunities for planning and implementing community based andrural development programs. These steps would lay foundation for long term sustainability o f CDCs. However, pending the Presidential approval o f the by-law, the MRRD through the community lead development teams based intheir provincial offices will continue to provide assistance to the CDCs, who will complete the mobilization cycle o f the ongoing NSP, to facilitate the next round o f CDC elections, and assist the CDCs in seeking additional finds from other ministries or donors/NGOs.
Sustainabilitv o fthe subproiects
At the level o findividual communities, subprojects sustainability is promotedthrough the NSP eligibility rules for subproject proposals, which require a commitment to contribute a minimum o f 10 percent o f capital costs and a plan to cover the costs o f operation and maintenance (O&M) o f community assets. Facilitating Partners will help build the required technical and financial management capacity in the communities to undertake
28  O&M. Afghan villages have a `traditional' institutional framework for voluntary labor mobilization (ashar) to create or maintain joint assets, which can respond to the NSP requirements for community contributions towards capital costs andO&M. Inthe case of rehabilitation or improvement o f irrigation systems, which comprise a significant share of the subprojects, `traditional' non-formal water user associations headed by `water masters' (rnirabs) exist throughout Afghanistan (although some have collapsed as a result o f conflict and population displacement), and undertake water distribution and maintenance o f local irrigation systems. Experience from other NGO implemented projects inAfghanistan (e.g. drinkingwater supply) have demonstrated that arrangements for user payment in cash, kind, or labor for maintenance services provided through the market have resulted inhighlevels o f asset sustainability. Inaddition, stringent measures have been included in the NSP I1 to improve the quality o f engineering design and construction quality o f subprojects.

1. Introduction
A weak Government's civil service infrastructure, particularly at provincial and district levels, and disrupted village level social and community level organizations characterized the start up o fthe implementationo fNSP in2003. At that time there was an acute shortage o f national staff and the available staff lacked skills and exposure to planning and implementation o f rural development programs. The Ministry o f Rural Rehabilitation and Development (MRRD), which was the anchor ministry o f the NSP, lacked operational, procurement and financial management procedures and guidelines required to plan and implement a nation wide community driven development program such as NSP. The communication infrastructure was limited, with no regular surface mail service between Kabul andprovinces.
Because o f this situation, during the first three years of implementation o f the NSP the MRRDhas been assisted by an internationally recruitedOversight Consultant to carry out the overall management o f the program. In addition, the facilitation o f and technical guidance for the village level project planning and implementation have been outsourced to 24 international and national NGOs, called facilitating partners (FPs). These FPs facilitated the mobilization o f the target communities to form democratically elected Community Development Councils (CDCs) and provided technical guidance to the CDCs for the management o f block grants and planning and implementation o f the subprojects at village level usingthe block grants.
The program was initially managed through a centralized system based in Kabul, due to the lack o f capacity at the provincial level. However, during the course o f the last two years five regional offices have been established, and regional and provincial management capacity has been slowly but gradually developed and strengthened, and decentralization o f project oversight has been gradually delegated to regional and provincial offices. The responsibilities for training and engineering support to FPs and CDCs have devolved to regional offices.
Most MRRD civil servants at the central and provincial levels have been integrated into the NSP management structure over the past three years. Two MRRD staff from every province have been seconded to the provincial NSP OC offices to provide additional engineering and monitoring support, as well as to learn the intricacies o f the program's processes andprocedures. The MRRD staff at the central level has been integrated across all program departments o f the OC to be a part o f the implementation and to learnhow the program operates. The OC has supported all o f these integrated staff with specific but limitedcapacity buildingtraining, as well as on-the-job mentoring.
Despite the public administration, staffing, skills, security and logistical constraints that prevailed in the country, these implementation arrangements have resulted in a rapid roll out o f the program covering nearly two thirds o f the rural villages o f the country to date.
54  The NSP i s now recognized by the government, rural communities as well as the international donor cpmmunity as a successhl community-driven, village-level infrastructure delivery, and institution buildingprogram.
However, these arrangements have also been subject o f criticism. It has been often noted that: the NSP reliance on the external oversight consultant has prevented capacity building o f the MRRD; the Technical Assistance cost was high; there was no clear separation o f core policy, donor coordination, external relations, fund raising and budget control functions o f the MRRD from the management oversight and operational responsibilities o f the OC; intra-ministerial coordination between the ongoing rural development programs within the MRRD was seen as ineffective; and collaboration and coordination o f the NSP with other ministries which are mandated for implementing various other complementary rural development programs have been weak at central, provincial anddistrict levels.
Taking into account these lessons and the challenges and constraints that continue to be posed by the operating environment, the NSP I1institutional arrangements build on the successful elements o f the existing structure, but they also introduce significant adjustments, with a special attention to the institutional strengthening of the MRRD and the decentralization o fthe program.

1. CountryContext
The Bank has gained substantial experience and understanding o f the procurement environment in Afghanistan through its involvement in the interim procurement arrangements put in place through Emergency Public Administration Project (EPAP) as well as with the institutions such as Afghanistan Reconstruction andDevelopment Services (ARDS) that is holding the current responsibility for government's procurement administration. As part o f the broader review o f Afghanistan's Public Finance Management (PFM) system, the Bank recently carried out an assessment o f the procurement environment inthe country based on the baseline andperformance indicators developed by a group o f institutions led by the World Bank and Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (0ECD)Development Assistance Committee (DAC).
The first key issue identified through the procurement assessment was the need for ownership and a champion inthe Government for reform, deepening o f capacity, ensuring integrity in the operation o f procurement systems, and promoting sound procurement among ministries."
A new Procurement Law has been adopted inNovember 2005 which radically transforms the legal and regulatory framework for the procurement administration o f Afghanistan. While it provides a very modern legal system for procurement, effective implementation o f the law may encounter difficulties in the current weak institutional structure and capacity o f the Government. It relies, for example, on the establishment o f a procurement policy unit (PPLJ) to ensure the implementation through the creation o f secondary legislation, standard bidding documents, provision of advice and creation o f the necessary information systems for advertising and data collection. It further relies on the development o f an independent complaints review mechanism to ensure enforcement. These institutional arrangements are yet to be inplace.
Inthe absence of adequate capacity to manage procurement activities effectively, some interim arrangements have been put in place to improve the procurement management o f the country. A central procurement facilitation service, ARDS has been established under the supervision o f Ministry of Economy. The Bank and the Government has agreed on a program for country wide procurement reform and capacity building, leading to the transition from centralizedto decentralized procurement services. The Bank funded Public Administration Capacity Building project (PACBP) is the primary instrument for implementing the program to strengthen capacity o f the line ministries to manage public procurement in an effective, transparent and accountable manner. However, the implementation o f the procurement capacity buildingstrategy has not made any significant progress yet due to lack o f coordination and delays in decision making within the Government. The envisaged radical changes to the procurement management environment expected from the new Law also require the urgent implementation o f a comprehensive human resources and capacity development program. The implementation o f the

1. CountryIssues
The Bank has gained substantial experience and understanding o f the financial management environment in Afghanistan through the large number o f projects under implementation over the past four years. The Public Administration Capacity Building Project (PACBP) i s the primaryinstrumentto continue and enhance the fiduciary measures put inplace during the past years to help ensure transparency and accountability for the fundingprovidedbythe Bank andother donors.
A PFM performance rating system using 28 high-level indicators that was developed by the Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability multi-agency partnership program (PEFA) was applied inAfghanistan inJune 2005. PEFA is comprised o f the World Bank, IMF, EC, and several other agencies. The system is structured around six core dimensions o f PFM performance: (i) budget credibility; (ii) comprehensiveness and transparency; (iii) policy-based budgeting; (iv) predictability and control inbudget execution; (v) accounting, recording, and reporting; and (vi) external scrutiny and audit.
Afghanistan's ratings against the PFM performance indicators generally portray a public sector where financial resources are, by and large, being used for their intended purposes. This has been accomplishedwith very highlevels o f support from international firms; this assistance will continue to be needed over the medium term if these ratings are to be maintained.
There is also much room for improvement. In spite o f undeniable gains made in reconstruction since the end o f 2001, the challenges facing Afghanistanremain immense; not least because o f the tenuous security situation in the region and continued prevalence o f a large illegal and illicit economy. The policy framework benchmarks have not yet been fully costed so various priorities are funded through the annual budgeting process. The rising costs o f the security sector constitute the major constraint on attainment o f fiscal sustainability. With regard to executive oversight, the national assembly will play an increasingly active role. All in all, the new national strategy has created highexpectations o f the executive which could prove to be quite difficult to meet.
The public sector, in spite o f considerable efforts to reform its core functions, remains extremely weak outside o f Kabul. The lack o f skilled staff in the civil service and the absence o f qualified counterparts inthe government after 30 years or war and conflicts is a bindingconstraint. Delays inreforming the pay structure andgrading o f civil servants have severely crippled the public administration o f the country. Domestic revenues lag behind expenditures by a factor o f ten to one. Large-scale corruption could emerge to undermine the government's efforts to enhance aid flows through national accounts. Capacities to track expenditures and monitor expenditure outcomes have improved, but they need rapid and substantial strengthening if progress toward the attainment o f national development targets is to be monitored. Currently, 75% of external revenues bypass government appropriation systems.
79  The World Bank is financing a Financial Management Advisor to assist the Ministry o f Finance, an Audit Advisor to assist the Control and Audit Office, and a Procurement Advisor to assist inProcurement-related activities. Also an Internal Audit function is being developed within the Ministry o f Finance with World Bank financing. USAID and earlier the IndianAid Assistance Program are also financing a team o f consultants and advisors to assist the D a Afghanistan Bank in local as well as foreign currency operations. The activities carried out under the existing Public Administration projects have helped the Government to ensure that appropriate fiduciary standards are maintained for public expenditures, including those supported bythe Bank andthe donor community.
Progress has been slower than expected inshifting from operations support provided by the three Advisors to capacity development andknowledge transfer to the civil servants. Given that, is expected that the Advisors will continue to be required for the medium term. Challenges still remain in attaining the agreed upon fiduciary standards and also to further enhance them. And to make matters more complex, the regulatory environment in Afghanistan has advanced significantly in the past three years. Unfortunately, even mastery o f basic skills inthe early environment does not fully qualify the civil servants to work effectively inthe new emerging environment.

1. Introduction
As o f the appraisal o fthe NSP 11,the ongoing NSP includes about 20,180 subprojects o f which about which 19,750 are ongoing, and 6,900 have been completed by the beneficiary communities using the block grants. A large majority o f these subprojects include, in the descending order o f the community demand, the new construction and refurbishment o f village level facilities such as: drinking water and sanitation; gravelled roads and culverts, irrigation works, village electrification; school buildings; public buildings (mosques, community centers, public baths etc.); andhealth clinics.
There i s an increasing demand for micro-hydro power projects for the communities. In addition, a small number o f non-engineering, income generation and livelihood promotion subprojects too have been financed. Communities have consistently prioritized small scale infrastructure projects and on average implement two subprojects with their block grant allocations. On average about 55% o f all projects involve productive infrastructure such as irrigation, roads and village electrification thereby promoting productivity and stimulating local economies. A futher 26% o f projects involve safe water and sanitation which assures better health for the communities. In addition, the NSP includes the construction o f 67 schools in different districts chosen by the communities under the District School Rehabilitation and Construction Window.
Drinking water facilities, roads and village electrification projects continue to be o f urgent importance in NSP I1as many communities lack access to potable water, basic services and markets and less than 5% o f rural households have access to power. The unprecedented winter snowfall o f 2005 in certain provinces and the consequent flooding caused an upsurge inprojects involving earth retaining walls and flood protection works. The NSP I1anticipates that projects involvingroads, water and electricity will continue to be fundamental priorities for the communities as the program rolls out to cover the entire country. There i s a recent trend inwhich a cluster o f adjoining communities pool up o f their block grant allocations to invest on larger and common infrastructure subprojects such as long irrigation canals, village roads and electricity supply lines from the main power gridto serve those cluster o fvillages. This trend i s likely to continue inthe NSP 11.
The planning, design and implementation o f these subprojects require adequate arrangements to ensure the design and construction quality o f the subprojects inNSP 11. In the NSP, there have been adequate arrangements to ensure the quality of the engineering design o f the subprojects through a systematic review o f the subprojects by the oversight consultant. Even with these arrangements, it has been found necessary to further improve the quality o f subprojects planningand design particularly inrespect of micro-hydro power projects and large and common infrastructure projects that would be implementedby a cluster o f communities usingthe pooled up block grant allocations.
97  While the planning and design o f the subprojects have been satisfactory, the previous World Bank NSP review missions have expressed concerns over the inadequate arrangements for construction quality assurance o f subprojects. Inadequate attention and arrangements for civil works construction quality is a national issue. However, construction quality o f subprojects cannot be compromised as nearly 88 percent of the block grants are invested for small scale subprojects. Individual and aggregate effect o f the poor quality would undermine both the sustainability o f the projects as well as the expected return on the investments.
Adequate arrangements for the construction quality assurance o f the subprojects will be established and enforced in NSP I1as per arrangements discussed and agreed with the MRRDas follows.

4. Specific arrangements for the Energy Sector
After more thantwo decades o fwar inAfghanistan, the civil infrastructures are damaged beyond repair and only a small percentage o f the population has access to irregular electricity supply from what remains o f the national grids. Several programs have been dealing with the rehabilitation o f the national power grid; however have so far focused mostly on urban supply, rehabilitation o f larger plants and grid trunks, leaving the sparse rural population completely unattended for.
The energy sources offering better decentralization potential, sustainability, and reliability over time are the renewables. Renewable energy resources include hydro (water), wind, both passive and photo voltaic solar, geothermal, processing and reuse o f biomass and other wastes. Efficient use o f renewable resources also includes energy- efficient architecture and demand side analysis: what types o f services do communities demand andwhat is their willingness to pay for it.
Unlike fossil fuels, renewable energy sources are generally equitably distributed; almost every community has some renewable resource available. In Afghanistan, renewable resources are known to be good, but have not yet been systematically quantified. Rural communities have been traditionally exploiting renewable natural resources, such as water, to produce energy, both mechanical and electrical. More efficient and durable technologies to harness renewable energy sources into electric power require relatively high investments, especially wind and photo voltaic. Therefore, to foster rural electrification and prevent excessive rural divide, consequent rampant urbanization, and general discontent, which hamper the stability and security o f the Country, rural communities inAfghanistan need to access appropriate technologies at reasonable cost.

Reducing opium production is one o f the greatest challenges facing Afghanistan. Opium i s central to the macroeconomy, contributing one third o f GDP and significant support for aggregate demand and the balance o f payments. Inthe rural economy, opium is a key livelihoods coping strategy for as many as 350,000 farm families, most o f them poor. 2. Governmentstrategy
Government's strategy to reduce and ultimately eliminate opium from the Afghan economy comprises essentially three elements. The first i s to improve governance and the rule o f law, strengthening public institutions and mechanisms to control drugs, together with the development o f responsible governance structures and the "social contract" at all levels from the community up. The second is to raise the general level o f economic activity and services, improving living standards and providing social protection. The third i s to emphasize indevelopment programs specific components that can have a significant impact on farmer behavior, with a focus on poorer farmers, laborers, andmore vulnerable areas.
3. World Bankapproach

The Bank screens all its activities in Afghanistan, both operations and analytical and advisory work, to ensure that counter-narcotics aspects are treated consistently and in a way that can make the maximum contribution to the national effort against drugs.

1. Introduction
Since September 2003, the Oversight Consultant (OC) established a Public Communication Unit (PCU) to raise awareness about the program's objectives and to communicate the program's success, primarilyto Afghans. The execution o f this strategy will fiather assist the NSP and MRRDinachieving their objectives and inensuring that the communication and information function properly adapts to the evolving needs o f the program.
This strategy is consistent with, and aims to achieve objectives o f the government and its commitments as expressed in the Interim Afghan National Development Strategy (I- ANDs). 2. Rationale
At the heart o f the National Solidarity Program is a human growth, empowerment and local governance process, based to a great extent on social, economic and political change. This change is dependent on several factors including the systematic access to knowledge and information by all stakeholders. Hence, strategic communication provides NSP I1 management with supporting tools for the achievement o f the program development objectives; it helps facilitate a common understanding among all participants, therefore creating a base for concerted action.
Undertaking a carefully considered communication program, to build public consensus and ownership o f the program remains an important element for the success o f the NSP 11.To the government's credit, significant communication activities are already ongoing at national level. The government capacity to engage in communication during the first three years o f NSP implementation has been admirable. As the program moves into its second phase it's important to ensure that communication activities carried out by PCU are sustained as a two -way communication mechanism that includes adequate feedback from key constituencies.
3. Background
As o f December 2005, PCU produced about 4 hours o f broadcast TV news, 15 hours of documentaries, 100 hours o f radio broadcast divided in features stories, news and soap opera episodes. It produced about 75,000 print media products (posters, brochures leaflets, poem books and news articles), eight exposure trips, and one national CDC congress. The total cost estimated o f the PCU i s about US$1.2 million a year. Potentialimpactsof various components
Activities envisaged under the project should not entail significant and negative environmental and social impacts, provided they are designed and implemented with due consideration o f environmental and social issues. Rather, most subprojects envisaged under the project should contribute to improving environmental and social conditions in rural Afghanistan. Adverse impacts may arise due to depletion or degradation o f natural resources such as stone, earth, water etc. used for construction o f small-scale infrastructure. Construction activities may cause limited, temporary, and localized negative impacts that can be mitigated through the implementation o f an appropriate social and environmental management plan. Certain types o f investments with negative environmental or social impacts cannot be undertaken and are included in a negative list o f prohibited investments. Interms of social impacts, the proposedproject falls inthe S- 3 category o f the Guidelines for Land and Asset Acquisition, Entitlements, and Compensation (Attachment 3).
No landacquisition is anticipated. Inthe current socio-political context inthe rural areas, involuntary land acquisition i s unlikely for the kind o f small-scale activities that will be undertaken under the proposedproject for two reasons. The first is, that local authorities do not have access to funds to purchase landor other assets if land acquisition were to be undertaken. The proposed emergency reconstruction operations are unlikely to pose a risk of damaging cultural property, as the subprojects will largely consist of small investments in community infrastructure and income generating activities, reconstruction of existing structures, and minor urban public works. ChanceFindProcedures
Chance find procedures are defined in the law on Maintenance of Historical and Cultural Monuments (Official Gazette, December 21, 1980), specifying the authorities and responsibilities of cultural heritage agencies if sites or materials are discovered in the course of project implementation. This law establishes that all moveable and immovable historical and cultural artifacts are state property, and further:
1. The responsibility for preservation, maintenance and assessment of historical and cultural monuments rests with the Archaeological Committee under the Ministry o f Information and Culture, which has representation at provincial level.
2. Whenever chance finds of cultural or historical artifacts (moveable and immovable) are made the Archaeological Committee should be informed. Should the continuation of work endanger the historical and cultural artifacts, the project work should be suspended untila solution is found for the preservation ofthese artifacts.
3. If a moveable or immovable historical or cultural artifact i s found inthe countryside o f a province, the provincial governor (wali) or district-in-charge (woluswal) should be informed within two weeks, and they should inform the Archaeological Committee. In case the immovable historical or cultural artifact i s found ina city, the provincial branch of the Department of Maintenance of Historical Values of the Ministry o f Information and Culture shouldbe informedwithin two weeks (art. 18). Ifthe find i s made withinthe center, the Archaeological Committee must be informed directly within one week (art. 25).
4. Failure to report a chance find within the stipulated time limit will be punished with a fine or imprisonment for aperiod of one week or upto one month (art. 72).
5. If someone intentionally damages a historical or cultural artifact, the culprit will pay compensation inaccordancewith the value of the artifact plus be imprisoned for a period o f one monthto ten years depending on the gravity o f the crime (art. 71).
150  In case of a chance find of moveable or immovable historical or cultural artifact, the implementing agency i s responsible for securing the artifact from theft, pilferage and damage untilthe responsibilityhasbeentaken over bythe relevantauthorities as specified above.
These procedures must be referred to as standard provisions in construction contracts, when applicable. Duringproject supervision, the Site Engineer will monitor that the above regulations relating to the treatment of any chance find encountered are observed.

doc.repnme: Afghanistan - Second Emergency National Solidarity Project
doc.abstracts: This grant for Afghanistan will support the national solidarity program's expansion to new districts to lay the foundations for strengthening community level governance, and support community-managed sub-projects comprising reconstruction and development that improve the access of rural communities to social and productive infrastructure and services. The grant will finance block grants to village communities, consultants for community facilitation and sub-project preparation, consultants for program management and monitoring, capacity building and implementation support for the implementing ministry, and consultants for external evaluation. The project will (i) empower local communities through the establishment of village level consultative decision making and representative local leadership as a basis for interaction within and between communities on the one hand, and with the administration and aid agencies on the other, and (ii) finance local level reconstruction, development, and capacity building leading to a decrease in poverty levels. Through these benefits, the project will also contribute to stability in Afghanistan. Likely risks are weak institutional capacity; a fragile security situation; elite capture of benefits, and misuse of funds. Appropriate mitigation measures have been proposed to address these risks.
